content.webTitle: The Resistance Now: the Brits shock the world again

fields.headline: The Resistance Now: the Brits shock the world again
fields.bodyText: Cor-blimey! Jeremy Corbyn’s performance in the British election last night – and what it could mean for progressives in the US – is dominating conversations so far at the People’s Summit, which is taking place in Chicago. Bernie Sanders is among those hailing the performance of Corbyn and Labour, who while running on a liberal platform, managed to wipe out the Conservative party’s majority – in an election some predicted Theresa May’s party would win by a landslide. “All over the world, people are rising up against austerity and massive levels of income and wealth inequality,” Sanders said on Friday morning. “People in the UK, the US and elsewhere want governments that represent all the people, not just the 1%. I congratulate Jeremy Corbyn for running a very effective campaign.” The Guardian is reporting from the summit on Friday and Saturday, and there was a palpable sense that the UK election result seems to have galvanized both the grassroots and progressive politicians up and down the ticket. Maybe it’s just because your Guardian correspondent has an English accent, but people seemed very keen to talk about British politics. Like Sanders, Corbyn has faced criticism from the centre of his party for being on its left, with internal detractors arguing he would be disastrous with voters. Ro Khanna, US congressman for California, told us that Corbyn’s win “should provide inspiration to Democrats here”. Now it’s the job of progressives, Khanna said, to “make the case to the Democratic leadership that a positive populist message is not just morally right, it’s strategically smart”. Coming up: the progressives who’ve already won Some of the most hotly anticipated Summit events were featuring progressives who have won office this year. Khalid Kamau, elected to the South Fulton, Georgia, city council in April, and Christine Pellegrino, elected to New York state assembly in May, both ran on progressive platforms. They’re at the People’s Summit to tell activists and elected-officials-to-be how they did it. Kamau campaigned for South Fulton – just outside Atlanta – on a platform that included included raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour, making voting day a holiday and decriminalizing marijuana. “People think that stuff will never work here in Georgia. But if you can get it to work here then you can scale it up to a national level,” he told the Guardian. Both Kamau and Pellegrino were backed by independent organizations such as Our Revolution and People for Bernie. Those groups encouraged activists to make phone calls and canvas on the candidates’ behalf. In Pellegrino’s case the result was remarkable: the former Sanders delegate became the first ever Democrat to represent New York state’s ninth district when she won her special election in May. If you’re at the summit The Guardian has a booth just in front of the main stage. We’ll be working from here or around here on Friday and Saturday so do come say hi. We could talk about Corbyn. Photo of the day Here’s Lord Buckethead, illustrating the less serious side of British politics. He ran against May in her Maidenhead constituency (high-profile members of parliament often attract irreverent opponents – May was also challenged by a man dressed as Elmo). Buckethead’s longshot candidacy garnered 249 votes, which was not enough to defeat May’s 37,718. Sign up for our weekly newsletter about the Resistance
